{{howto|date=January 2013}} The term "'''tornado preparedness'''" refers to [[safety]] precautions made before the arrival of and during a [[tornado]]. Historically, the steps taken have varied greatly, depending on location, or time remaining before a tornado was expected. For example, in rural areas, people might prepare to enter an external [[storm cellar]], in case the main building collapses, and thereby allow exit without needing rescue from the main building as in urban areas. Because [[tropical storm]]s have spawned many tornadoes, hurricane preparations also involve tornadoes. The term "tornado preparedness" has been used by government agencies, emergency response groups, schools,<ref> "Tornado Preparedness Tips for School Administrators", NOAA.gov, 2010, web: [http://www.spc.noaa.gov/faq/tornado/school.html NOAA-sch]. </ref> insurance companies, and others.
== Understanding the dangers == Preparedness involves knowing the major dangers to avoid. Some tornadoes are the most violent storms in nature.<ref name="Ftorn"> "Tornado", FEMA.gov, August 2010, web: [http://www.fema.gov/hazard/tornado/index.shtm FEMA-tornado] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429174402/http://www.fema.gov/hazard/tornado/index.shtm |date=2011-04-29 }}. </ref> Tornadoes have varied in strength, and some tornadoes have been mostly invisible due to a lack of loose dirt or debris in the funnel cloud.<ref name=Ftorn/> Spawned from severe [[thunderstorm]]s, tornadoes have caused fatalities and devastated neighborhoods within seconds of arrival. [[File:Tornado with no funnel.jpg|right|thumb|A tornado with no obvious funnel from the upper clouds, although the rotating dust cloud indicates strong winds at the surface.]]
A tornado operates as a rotating, funnel-shaped cloud that extends downward from a thunderstorm, to the ground, with swirling winds which have reached {{convert|300|mph}}.<ref name=Ftorn/> The wind speed might be difficult to imagine: traveling the length of a U.S. [[American football|football field]] within 1 second<ref> A speed of 300 miles per hour is 300*5280 = 1,584,000 feet per hour, or 440 feet (134 m) per second. </ref> (over {{convert|130|m|ft|sp=us|disp=or}} per second). Damage paths have been in excess of {{convert|spell=in |1|mi|km|adj=mid|wide}} and {{convert|50|mi|km|disp=x| long (|)}}.<ref name=Ftorn/>
Not all tornadoes are easily seen. A tornado funnel can be transparent until reaching an area with loose dirt and debris.<ref name=Ftorn/> Also, some tornadoes have been seen against sunlit areas, but rain or nearby low-hanging clouds has obscured other tornadoes. Occasionally, tornadoes have developed so suddenly, so rapidly, that little, if any, advance warning was possible.<ref name=Ftorn/>
Before a tornado strikes an area, the wind has been known to die down and the air to become very still.<ref name=Ftorn/>{{dubious|Calm before the storm|reason=Not necessarily true|date=January 2013}} A cloud of debris has sometimes marked the bottom of a tornado even when the funnel was not visible. Tornadoes typically occur along the trailing edge of a thunderstorm.
The following is a summary of typical tornadoes:<ref name=Ftorn/>
:* They may strike quickly, with little or no warning. :* They may appear nearly transparent until dust and debris are picked up or a cloud forms in the funnel. :* The average tornado moves Southwest to Northeast in the U.S., but tornadoes have been known to move in any direction. :* The average forward speed of a tornado is {{convert|30|mph}}, but has varied from stationary to {{convert|70|mph|abbr=on}}. :* Tornadoes can also accompany tropical storms and hurricanes as they move onto land. :* [[Waterspout]]s are tornadoes that form over water. :* Tornadoes are most frequently reported east of the Rocky Mountains during spring and summer months. :* Peak tornado season in the southern [[U.S. state]]s is March through May; in the northern states, it is late spring through early summer. :* Tornadoes are most likely to occur between 3 p.m. and 9 p.m. (local time), but have occurred at other times.<ref name=Ftorn/>
== Steps when expecting storms to arrive == The U.S. [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA) has advised the following precautions before a storm reaches an area:<ref name="Fprec"> "What to do Before a Tornado", FEMA.gov, August 2010, web: [http://www.fema.gov/hazard/tornado/to_before.shtm FEMA-to] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110502103857/http://www.fema.gov/hazard/tornado/to_before.shtm |date=2011-05-02 }}. </ref> [[File:CompleteTornadoemergencykit.jpg|thumb|Example of a tornado emergency kit ]] :* Be alert to the changing weather conditions. :* Listen to [[NOAA Weather Radio]] and/or [[Skywarn]], or to local commercial radio or television newscasts for the latest information. :* Watch various common danger signs, including: ::* dark, often greenish-colored sky;<ref name=Fprec/> ::* large [[hail]] stones; ::* a large, dark, low-lying cloud (particularly if rotating); ::* loud roar of wind, sounding similar to a [[freight train]]. Upon seeing an approaching storm or noticing any of the danger signs, they were advised to prepare to take shelter immediately,<ref name=Ftorn/> such as moving to a [[safe room]], internal stairway, or other safe-haven area.
All individuals and families should have a disaster preparedness kit made prior to tornado. According to FEMA the kit should include items needed to shelter in place in the event of a disaster such as a tornado for up to 72 hours following impact.
== Actions taken during tornadoes == During August 2010, FEMA advised people to perform the following actions when a tornado struck.<ref name="Fdur"> "What to Do During a Tornado", FEMA.gov, August 2010, web: [http://www.fema.gov/hazard/tornado/to_during.shtm FEMA-dur] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110425051859/http://www.fema.gov/hazard/tornado/to_during.shtm |date=2011-04-25 }}. </ref> {| class=wikitable style="margin-right:0em;" ! Location || Action taken |- | valign=top | In a structure (e.g. residence, small building, school, nursing home, hospital, factory, shopping center, high-rise building,restaurant) | valign=top | They were to enter a pre-designated shelter area such as a [[safe room]], basement, [[storm cellar]], or the lowest building level.<ref name=Fdur/> If there was no basement, then to the center of an interior room on the lowest level (closet, interior hallway) away from corners, windows, doors, and outside walls. The goal has been to put as many walls as possible between there and the outside. They were advised to get under a sturdy table and use arms to protect head and neck, and not open windows.<ref name=Fdur/> |- | valign=top | In a vehicle, trailer, or mobile home | valign=top | They were advised to leave immediately and enter the lowest floor of a sturdy, nearby building or a [[storm shelter]].<ref name=Fdur/> Mobile homes, even if tied down, offer little protection from tornadoes.<ref name=Fdur/> If a car is flipped by high winds, there is also the danger of broken glass. |- | valign=top | On the outside with no shelter | valign=top | They were advised to lie flat in a nearby ditch or depression and cover head with their hands.<ref name=Fdur/> Also, to beware of the potential for flooding there.
They were advised to not stay under an overpass or bridge (where winds or debris might be funneled). It was safer to be in a low, flat location.<ref name=Fdur/>
The advice was to never try to outrun a tornado in urban or congested areas in a car or truck, but instead, to leave the vehicle immediately for safe shelter.
Flying debris from tornadoes causes most fatalities and injuries.<ref name=Fdur/> |} Because some preparations vary, depending on location, people have been advised to consult their local area preparedness plans, rather than assume the plans are similar for all areas, such as which local buildings have been designated as storm shelters.
A 2012 study of tornado injuries found that wearing a helmet such as those used for American football or bicycling, is an effective way to reduce injuries and deaths from head trauma.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uab.edu/icrc/tornado_helmet_com.html|title=ICRC|website=www.uab.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/05/26/136645164/how-to-survive-a-tornado-plan-ahead-avoid-debris|title=How To Survive A Tornado: Plan Ahead, Avoid Debris|publisher=}}</ref> As of 2012, the CDC endorsed only general head protection, but recommended that if helmets are to be used, they be kept close by to avoid wasting time searching for them.<ref>{{cite web|date=2012-05-17|accessdate=2013-08-18|title=Helmet and Tornado Statement|url=http://emergency.cdc.gov/disasters/tornadoes/}}</ref>
After the [[2013 Moore tornado]], it became apparent that thousands of people attempt to flee major tornadoes, and this has been credited with reducing the death toll. However, during this event some people were killed as the tornado passed over the traffic jam caused by the impromptu evacuation. In addition to urban traffic, evacuation can also be hampered by flash flooding produced by associated thunderstorms, and the need to be certain about the position and direction of the tornado. Others who did not flee the Moore tornado were also killed because the buildings they were hiding in were completely destroyed, highlighting the need for storm shelters and safe rooms constructed specifically to withstand very high winds.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/06/01/187876338/no-universal-best-practice-to-save-yourself-from-tornadoes|agency=NPR|author=Wade Goodwin|date=2013-06-01|accessdate=2013-08-18}}</ref>
== Long-term preparations == Depending on location, various safe-haven areas have been prepared. The goal has been to avoid outer walls which might collapse when a roof section becomes airborne and the walls below lose their upper support: many interior rooms resist collapse longer, due to smaller walls interconnected to each other, while outer walls deflect the force of the winds. Because [[mobile home]]s typically lack foundation anchors and present a large surface-area sail (to catch wind), the advice has been to seek a safe haven elsewhere, such as in a stronger nearby building.<ref name=Fdur/> When a mobile home begins to roll, people have been injured by hitting objects inside, or being crushed when a trailer suddenly hits the ground and begins to collapse around them.
In a multi-story building, an internal stairway (away from broken windows) often acts as a safe haven, due to the stairs reinforcing the walls and blocking any major debris falling from above. If a stairway is lined with windows, then there would be the danger of flying glass, so an interior stairway, or small inner room, would be preferable.
In private homes, some similar stairway rooms have been used, or an interior room/closet kept clear to quickly allow entry when a storm is seen or heard approaching (the wind roar intensifies, sounding like a swift "[[freight train]]" coming nearer, louder).<ref name=Ftorn/> With weeks or months to prepare, an interior [[safe room]] can be constructed, with space for emergency water, food and flashlights, and a telephone to call for rescue if the exit becomes blocked by falling debris. Some above-ground safe rooms have been built with steel-[[rebar]] rods in cement-filled [[cinder block]]s, to withstand winds of {{convert|250|mph}}. Rural homes might have an outside [[storm cellar]], or other external bunker, to avoid being trapped within a collapsing house. In rural homes, generators are also helpful to maintain power with enough fuel for a few days.
There were no building codes requiring tornado shelters nor specifically designed to prevent tornado damage<ref name="livescience">{{cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/13962-tornado-safety-building-codes.html|title=Why Aren't There Tornado Safety Building Codes?|publisher=}}</ref> until the [[2011 Joplin tornado]] prompted a local ordinance requiring [[hurricane tie]]s or similar fasteners. The state of Oklahoma adopted the minimum U.S. standard that year for the first time, but did not add high-wind protections like those in Florida designed to protect against hurricanes.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/08/us-usa-tornadoes-construction-insight-idUSBRE95707L20130608 | work=Reuters | title=Insight: In tornado alley, building practices boost damage | date=2013-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stateimpact.npr.org/oklahoma/2013/07/03/moore-officials-delay-vote-on-strengthening-building-codes/|title=Moore Officials Delay Vote on Upgrading Building Codes for Tornadoes - StateImpact Oklahoma|first=By Joe|last=Wertz|publisher=}}</ref> Other states in Tornado Alley have no statewide building codes. The chance of any given location in Tornado Alley getting hit by an F-2 tornado (strong enough to do major structural damage and exceeding the 90 mph guideline for straightline winds) is about 1 every 4,000-5,000 years; in other areas the annual probability is one in several million.<ref name="livescience" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825011156/http://www.sciencenews.org/articles/20020511/bob9.asp|title=Tornado Alley, USA: Science News Online, May 11, 2002|date=25 August 2006|publisher=}}</ref> The most stringent building codes only require earthquake strengthening for a 1 in every 500-1,000 year probability.<ref name="livescience" />
The U.S. [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] has spent tens millions of dollars subsidizing the construction of shelters and safe rooms in both private and public buildings.<ref name="reuters" /> Many buildings in Tornado Alley do not have basements, because unlike in more northern areas, there is no need for a deep foundation to get below the [[frost line]], in some places the [[water table]] is high, and expansion and contraction of clay-heavy soils can produce additional pressure on buildings that can cause leaks if not reinforced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/05/21/185857916/why-oklahomans-dont-like-basements|title=Why Oklahomans Don't Like Basements|publisher=}}</ref>
== Medical preparations == Having a [[first aid kit]] in the safe haven is advised to help victims recover from minor injuries. People needing prescription medications could have a medicine bag ready to take to shelter. Some people have reported their "ears popping" due to the change in air pressure, but those effects seem to be temporary. Covering people with mattresses or cushions has helped avoid injury from flying debris,<ref name=Fdur/> as walls collapsed nearby.
Injuries sustained during a tornado vary in nature and in severity. The most common injuries experienced during a tornado are complex contaminated soft tissue wounds and account for more than 50% of the cases seen by emergency rooms following a tornado. These wounds will most likely be contaminated with soil and foreign bodies due to high wind speeds caused by tornadoes. Fractures are the second most common injury obtained after a tornado strikes and account for up to 30% of total injuries. Head injuries are also commonly reported during a tornado, but severe head injuries only account for less than 10% of the total. Even though only 10% of reported head injuries are severe, they are the most common cause of death following a tornado. Blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen are also injuries obtained following a tornado, but only account for less than 10% of overall injuries.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hogan|first=David|title=Disaster Medicine|year=2007|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia, PA|page=200}}</ref>
==Tornado drills== [[File:Tornado drill.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Students participate in a tornado drill, lining up along an interior wall and covering their heads.]] Tornado drills are an important element in tornado preparedness. Like any other safety drills, they increase chances of correct response to a real tornado threat.
Most states in the midwestern and southern United States conduct a statewide tornado drill in late winter or early spring in preparation for the severe weather season. During these drills, the [[National Weather Service]] issues test [[tornado warning]]s, and local [[Emergency Alert System]]s and/or NOAA Weather Radio (normally as a Required Weekly Test or Required Monthly Test; Live Tornado Warning Codes can only be used if a waiver from the FCC is granted since "Live Code Testing" is prohibited per regulations) are activated along with outdoor warning sirens. Schools and businesses may also conduct a tornado drill simultaneously.
A '''tornado drill''' is a procedure of practicing to take cover in a specified location in the event that a [[tornado]] strikes an area. This [[:category:Safety drills|safety drill]] is an important element of tornado preparedness.<ref>"Disaster Prep 101", {{ISBN|0942369033}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=8gYJ8wR720QC&pg=PA154 pp154-155]</ref>
Generally, a signal is given, such as a series of tones (ex. Continuous Tone), or a voice announcement. Upon receiving the signal, building occupants of schools, hospitals, factories, shopping centers, etc. proceed to a designated location, usually an interior room or corridor with no windows, and assume a protective position.<ref name="Florida">{{cite web|url=http://greatamericanstormsheltersal.com/florida-disaster/|title=Florida Disaster|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="Plano">{{cite web |url=http://www.pisd.edu/about.us/safety/disaster.policy.shtml |title=Plano, Texas |publisher=Pisd.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514044534/http://pisd.edu/about.us/safety/disaster.policy.shtml |archivedate=2013-05-14 |df= }}</ref>
In homes and small buildings one must go to the basement or an interior room on the lowest floor (closet, bathroom), to stay away from glass.
Cars and mobile homes must be abandoned, if there is small chance to drive away.
In some jurisdictions, schools are required to conduct regular tornado drills, though generally less frequently than [[fire drill]]s.
===Tornado drills by state===
{{expand section|date=February 2013}} In many states tornado drills are part of the Severe Weather Awareness Week. *Alabama<ref>[http://www2.alabamas13.com/news/2010/feb/24/statewide_tornado_drill_wednesday-ar-399602/]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *Florida<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/content/news/articles/cfn/2013/2/14/florida_tornado_dril.html ]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *Georgia *Indiana *Iowa<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qconline.com/archives/qco/display.php?id=587563|title=Dispatch Argus - Historical Newspapers|publisher=}}</ref> *Ohio *Minnesota<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dps.mn.gov/divisions/hsem/weather-awareness-preparedness/Pages/severe-weather-tornado-drill-day.aspx|title=Weather Safety - Tornado Drill Day|website=dps.mn.gov}}</ref> *Missouri<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox4kc.com/2012/03/13/missouri-conducting-state-wide-tornado-drill/|title=Missouri Conducting State-Wide Tornado Drill|date=13 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref> *Texas *Virginia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vaemergency.gov/readyvirginia/stay-informed/tornado/conductdrill|title=Tornado Drill 2018 - Virginia Department of Emergency Management|date=4 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref> *Wisconsin<ref>[http://readywisconsin.wi.gov/tornado/Tornado%202012%20Drill%20Info%20Sheet.pdf]</ref> *North Carolina <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsoctv.com/news/weather/statewide-tornado-drill-part-severe-weather-awaren/nd5bC/|title=Things to know: Tornado safety tips|first=|last=EndPlay|date=20 April 2015|publisher=}}</ref>

[[File:yuhuastone.jpg|Yuhua stones|thumb]]
The '''Yuhua stone''' ({{zh|s=雨花石|p=''yuhua shi''|l=rain flower stone}}) is a special kind of stone found in [[Nanjing]], China, due to the unique geology of the area. Yuhua stones, or pebbles, are of sedimentary origin and consist of minerals including quartz and other silicates. They are found in the [[Yangtze River]], polished smooth by the action of water.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zgyhsw.com/post/370.html |title=雨花石形成分析 - 南京雨花石 - 中国雨花石网 |publisher=Zgyhsw.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-22|trans-title=Stone formation analysis - Nanjing stone - Chinese stone Network}}</ref> Colors include red, rose, yellow, green, and white.<ref>Xu Xiaomin, "Collector of Magic Pebbles". Shanghai Star, 11 January 2000. [http://app1.chinadaily.com.cn/star/history/00-01-11/l05-magic.html]</ref>
==Legend== The origin of the Yuhua Stone is told through the legend of a Chinese monk named Yunguang (雲光) who lived during the [[Liang dynasty]]. Yunguang used to travel around the country to deliver sermons.One day, He travelled to Nanjing, there, he sat on the [[Guanghua Gate]] for three days, talking about his concept, without eating or drinking. According to the legend, his sincerity moved God deeply, so God rained thousands of colourful flowers from the sky to reward him. When the flowers touched the ground, they turned into the Yuhua Stone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cathay.ce.cn/special01/tea/jiangsu/yuhuacha/200604/11/t20060411_6668023.shtml |title=雨花石传说——华夏文明——中国经济网 |publisher=Cathay.ce.cn |date= |accessdate=2011-12-22|trans-title=Stone legends - Chinese Civilization - China Economic Net}}</ref>
==Description== The stone is known for its beautiful patterns, often imagined to look like animals or flowers.
==Idiom== "{{zh|s=天花乱坠|p=TianHualuanZhui}}", means lots of flowers falling from the sky
==See also== *[[Natural flower stone]]
